newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan pursues Afghan ceasefire efforts.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan pursues Afghan ceasefire efforts.

text.p: Pakistani Interior Minister Naseerullah Babar said on Tuesday he hoped his efforts to broker a ceasefire between Afghan factions would bear fruit soon.

"I am more than hopeful (for a ceasefire accord) because in principle they have all agreed," Babar, who has been shuttling between opposing faction leaders, told a news conference. "The ceasefire will be applicable all across Afghanistan."
He said he was expecting a "positive" response from Uzbek militia chief Abdul Rashid Dostum from the northern town of Mazar-i-Sharif "today or tomorrow".
Babar said the draft agreement envisaged a ceasefire between the radical Islamic Taleban movement now ruling Kabul and forces loyal to ousted government military commander Ahmed Shah Masood.
The two sides were still trading fire on a plain north of Kabul on Tuesday, witnesses said.

Babar said the proposed ceasefire agreement provided for an exchange of prisoners and bodies, as well as formation of a 12-member commission representing the Taleban and its opponents -- Dostum, Masood and Shi'ite Moslem leader Karim Khalili.
He said the agreement should be under United Nations auspices to carry more weight, adding that the Pakistani Foreign Ministry had briefed U.N. officials on his mission.
"We feel we cannot do it alone," Babar said. "We feel the United Nations has to be there."
U.N. Special Envoy Norbert Holl, conducting separate efforts to arrange a ceasefire, said on Monday that no single country -- an apparent reference to Pakistan -- could bring peace to Afghanistan.
The main obstacle to a ceasefire agreement at the moment appears to be a demand by Masood that talks on demilitarising Kabul should start as soon as the truce is in place.
Babar described this as an "unfair condition" that went beyond the terms of the proposed ceasefire accord.
"We said that when the commission sits, this can be discussed," he added.
